tools: three {@variantrule musical instrument|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6|musical instruments} of your choice
one {@item musical instrument|PHB} of your choice
Choose one type of {@item Artisan's Tools|PHB} or {@item Musical Instrument|PHB}

classFeature.name: Bardic Inspiration
entries: You can supernaturally inspire others through words, music, or dance. This inspiration is represented by your Bardic Inspiration die, which is a {@dice d6}.

entries.name: Using Bardic Inspiration
entries: As a Bonus Action, you can inspire another creature within 60 feet of yourself who can see or hear you. That creature gains one of your Bardic Inspiration dice. A creature can have only one Bardic Inspiration die at a time.

Once within the next hour when the creature fails a {@variantrule D20 Tests|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6|d20 Test}, the creature can roll that die and add the number rolled to the {@dice d20}, potentially turning the failure into a success. A Bardic Inspiration die is expended when it's rolled.

entries.name: Number of Uses
entries: You can confer a Bardic Inspiration die a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

entries.name: At Higher Levels
entries: Your Bardic Inspiration die changes when you reach certain Bard levels, as shown in the Bardic Die column of the Bard table. The die becomes a {@dice d8} at 5th level, a {@dice d10} at 10th level, and a {@dice d12} at 15th level.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast Spells through your bardic arts. See the Player's Handbook for the rules on spellcasting. The information below details how you use those rules as a Bard.

entries.name: Chosen Spell List
entries: At 1st level, choose a spell list: Arcane, Divine, or Primal. The chosen list is your Bard spell list and represents the magical tradition in which you learned your bardic arts. Whichever list you choose, it includes the {@spell Vicious Mockery|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} cantrip for you.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know two cantrips of your choice from your Bard spell list.
Whenever you gain a Bard level, you can replace one of your cantrips with another cantrip of your choice from your Bard spell list.
When you reach 4th and 10th level in this class, you learn another cantrip of your choice from your Bard spell list, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Bard table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Bard table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of 1st+ Level
entries: You prepare the list of spells of 1st level and higher that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose four 1st-level spells from your Bard spell list.

The number of spells on your list also increases as you gain Bard levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Bard table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional spells from your Bard spell list until the number of spells on your list matches the number on the table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a 3rd-level Bard, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination.

If another Bard feature gives spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells on the list you prepare with this Spellcasting feature, but those spells otherwise follow the rules in this feature.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you gain a Bard level, you can replace one spell on your list with another spell for which you have spell slots and that is on your Bard spell list.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your Spellcasting Ability for your Bard spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item musical instrument|SCAG} as a Spellcasting Focus for the spells you cast with your Bard features.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} in two of your Skill Proficiencies of your choice.
{@skill Performance} and {@skill Persuasion} are iconic choices for a Bard if you have Proficiency in them.

classFeature.name: Jack of All Trades
entries: You can add half your Proficiency Bonus (round down) to any ability check you make that uses a skill proficiency you lack and that doesn't otherwise use your Proficiency Bonus.
For example, if you make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check and lack {@skill Athletics} proficiency, you can add half your Proficiency Bonus to the check.

classFeature.name: Bard Subclass
entries: You gain a Bard subclass of your choice: College of Dance, College of Glamour, College of Lore, or College of Valor. Subclasses are detailed after this class's description.
A subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Bard levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Bard level and lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another {@5etools Ability Score Improvement|feats.html} of your choice.

classFeature.name: Font of Inspiration
entries: You now also regain all your expended uses of Bardic Inspiration when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.
In addition, if you have no uses of Bardic Inspiration left, you can give yourself one use by expending a spell slot (no action required). You can do so only once per turn.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Bard Subclass.

classFeature.name: Countercharm
entries: You can use musical notes or words of power to disrupt mind-influencing effects. If you or a creature within 30 feet of you fails a saving throw against an effect that applies the {@condition Charmed} or {@condition Frightened} condition, you can use your Reaction to cause the save to be rerolled, and the new roll has Advantage.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} in two of your Skill Proficiencies of your choice.

classFeature.name: Magical Secrets
entries: You have collected magical knowledge from a wide spectrum of disciplines. As a result, your Bard Spell list now includes the {@variantrule Arcane Spells|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6|Arcane}, {@variantrule Divine Spells|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6|Divine}, or {@variantrule Primal Spells|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6|Primal}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Bard Subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Superior Inspiration
entries: When you roll Initiative and have no uses of Bardic Inspiration left, you regain two expended uses of it.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Words of Creation
entries: You have mastered two of the prime Words of Creation: the words of life and death. You therefore always have the {@spell Power Word Heal|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} and {@spell Power Word Kill|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} spells prepared, and when you cast either spell, you can target a second creature with the spell, provided that creature is within 10 feet of the first target.

classFeature.name: Divine Order
entries: You have dedicated yourself to one of the following sacred roles of your choice:

items.name: Protector
entries: Trained for battle, you gain Martial Weapon Proficiency and Heavy {@variantrule Armor Training|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

items.name: Thaumaturge
entries: You know one extra cantrip from the Divine spell list (see your Spellcasting feature for information on preparing spells). In addition, your mystical connection to the divine gives you a bonus to your Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) checks. The bonus equals your Wisdom modifier (minimum of +1).

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast spells through prayer, meditation, and devotion. See the Player's Handbook for the rules on spellcasting. The information below details how you use those rules as a Cleric.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know three cantrips of your choice from the Divine spell list. Rather than choosing, you may start with Guidance, Sacred Flame, and Thaumaturgy.

Whenever you gain a Cleric level, you can replace one of your cantrips with another cantrip of your choice from the Divine spell list. When you reach 4th and 10th level in this class, you learn another cantrip of your choice from the Divine spell list, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Cleric table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Cleric table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of 1st+ Level
entries: You prepare the list of spells of 1st level and higher that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose four 1st-level spells from the Divine spell list. Rather than choosing, you may start with Bless, Cure Wounds, Guiding Bolt, and Shield of Faith.

The number of spells on your list also increases as you gain Cleric levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Cleric table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional spells from the Divine spell list until the number of spells on your list matches the number on the table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a 3rd-level Cleric, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination.

If another Cleric feature gives spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells on the list you prepare with this Spellcasting feature, but those spells otherwise follow the rules in this feature.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, you can change your list of prepared spells, replacing one or more of the spells there with other Divine spells for which you have spell slots. Preparing a new list requires time spent in prayer and meditation: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell you add to the list.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your Spellcasting Ability for your Cleric spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a Holy Symbol as a Spellcasting Focus for the spells you prepare for this class.

classFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: You gain the ability to channel divine energy directly from the Outer Planes, using that energy to fuel magical effects. You start with two such effects: Divine Spark and Turn Undead, each of which is described below. Each time you use your Channel Divinity, you choose which effect to create, and you gain additional effect options at higher levels in this class.

You can use Channel Divinity twice. You regain one expended use when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}. You gain additional uses when you reach certain Cleric levels, as shown in the Channel Divinity column of the Cleric table.
If a Channel Divinity effect requires a saving throw, the DC equals the Spell Save DC from this class's Spellcasting feature.

entries.name: Divine Spark
entries: As a {@action Magic|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} action, you point your Holy Symbol at another creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself and focus divine energy at them. Roll {@dice 1d8} and add your Wisdom modifier. You either restore Hit Points to the creature equal to that total or force the creature to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes Necrotic or Radiant (your choice) damage equal to that total. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage (round down).
You roll an additional {@dice d8} when you reach certain Cleric levels: 7th level ({@dice 2d8}), 13th level ({@dice 3d8}), and 18th level ({@dice 4d8}).

entries.name: Turn Undead
entries: As a {@action Magic|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} action, you present your Holy Symbol and speak a prayer censuring Undead creatures. Each Undead within 30 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw. If the creature fails its saving throw, it has the {@condition Frightened} and {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} conditions for 1 minute. This effect ends early on the creature if it takes any damage, you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition, or you die.

classFeature.name: Cleric Subclass
entries: You gain a Cleric subclass of your choice: Life Domain, Light Domain, Trickery Domain, or War Domain. Subclasses are detailed after this class's description.

A subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Cleric levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Cleric level and lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Smite Undead
entries: You can cause your Turn Undead feature to smite the undying; whenever you use Turn Undead, you can roll a number of d8s equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of {@dice 1d8}) and add the rolls together. Each Undead that fails its saving throw against that use of Turn Undead takes Radiant damage equal to the roll's total. This damage doesn't end the turn effect.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Cleric Subclass.

classFeature.name: Blessed Strikes
entries: Divine power infuses you in battle. You gain one of the following options of your choice:

items.name: Divine Strike
entries: Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with an attack with a weapon, you can cause the target to take an extra {@dice 1d8} Necrotic or Radiant (your choice) damage.

items.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: You add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any Divine cantrip.
If you get either option from another source, you use only the option you chose for this feature.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Commune
entries: In the past, you have reached the divine source of your power through prayer. Now you can also have brief conversations; you always have the {@spell Commune} spell prepared.

classFeature.name: Divine Intervention
entries: You can call on your deity or pantheon to intervene on your behalf. As a {@action Magic|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6|Magic Action}, choose any Divine spell of 5th level or lower that doesn't require a Reaction to cast. As part of the same action, you cast that spell without expending a spell slot or needing material components. You then can't use this feature again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Improved Blessed Strikes
entries: The option you chose for Blessed Strikes grows more powerful:

items.name: Divine Strike
entries: The extra damage of your Divine Strike increases to {@dice 2d8}.

items.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: When you cast a Divine cantrip and deal damage to a creature with it, you can give vitality to yourself or another creature within 60 feet of yourself, granting a number of Temporary Hit Points equal to twice your Wisdom modifier.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Cleric Subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Greater Divine Intervention
entries: You are able to call on even more powerful divine intervention. When you use your Divine Intervention feature, you can choose Wish when you select a spell. If you do so, you can't use Divine Intervention again until you finish {@dice 2d4} Long Rests.
When you cast {@spell Wish} with this feature, you are immune to the stress caused by using Wish to do something other than casting a spell.

classFeature.name: Druidic
entries: You know Druidic, the secret language of Druids. While learning this ancient tongue, you also unlocked the magic of speaking to animals; you always have the {@spell Speak with Animals} spell prepared.

You can use Druidic to leave hidden messages. You and others who know Druidic automatically spot such a message. Others spot the message's presence with a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check but can't decipher it without magic.

classFeature.name: Primal Order
entries: You have dedicated yourself to one of the following sacred roles of your choice:

items.name: Magician
entries: You know one extra cantrip from the Primal spell list (see your Spellcasting feature for information on preparing spells). In addition, your mystical connection to nature gives you a bonus to your Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) checks. The bonus equals your Wisdom modifier (minimum of +1).

items.name: Warden
entries: Trained for battle, you gain Martial Weapon proficiency and Medium {@variantrule Armor Training|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast spells through studying the mystical forces of nature. See the Player's Handbook for the rules on spellcasting. The information below details how you use those rules as a Druid.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know two cantrips of your choice from the Primal spell list. Rather than choosing, you may start with Druidcraft and Produce Flame.
Whenever you gain a Druid level, you can replace one of your cantrips with another cantrip of your choice from the Primal spell list.
When you reach 4th and 10th level in this class, you learn another cantrip of your choice from the Primal spell list, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Druid table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Druid table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of 1st+ Level
entries: You prepare the list of spells of 1st level and higher that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose four 1st-level spells from the Primal spell list. Rather than choosing, you may start with Animal Friendship, Cure Wounds, Faerie Fire, and Thunderwave.

The number of spells on your list also increases as you gain Druid levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Druid table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional spells from the Primal spell list until the number of spells on your list matches the number on the table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a 3rd-level Druid, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination.

If another Druid feature gives spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells on the list you prepare with this Spellcasting feature, but those spells otherwise follow the rules in this feature.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, you can change your list of prepared spells, replacing one or more of the spells there with other Primal spells for which you have spell slots. Preparing a new list requires time spent in meditation: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell you add to the list.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your Spellcasting Ability for your Druid Spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a Druidic Focus as a Spellcasting Focus for the spells you prepare for this class.

classFeature.name: Wild Companion
entries: You can summon a nature spirit that assumes an animal form to aid you. As a {@action Magic|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6|Magic Action}, you can expend a spell slot or a use of Wild Shape to cast the {@spell Find Familiar} spell without material components.
When you cast the spell in this way, the familiar is a Fey, and it disappears when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

classFeature.name: Wild Shape
entries: The power of nature infuses you, allowing you to assume the form of an animal. As a Bonus Action, you transform into a Beast form that you have learned for this feature (see "Known Forms" below). You stay in that form for a number of hours equal to half your Druid level (round down) or until you use Wild Shape again, have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition, or die. You can also leave the form early as a Bonus Action.

entries.name: Known Forms
entries: You start knowing three forms for this feature, chosen from among Beast stat blocks that have a maximum Challenge Rating of 1/4 and that lack a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}. Rather than choosing, you may start with the Riding Horse, Spider, and Wolf. Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, you can replace one of your known forms with another eligible form.

When you gain certain Druid levels, you learn additional forms, and the maximum Challenge Rating for your forms increases, as shown in the Beast Shapes table. In addition, starting at 8th level, you can adopt a form that has a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

entries.name: Number of Uses
entries: You can use Wild Shape twice. You regain one expended use when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.
You gain additional uses when you reach certain Druid levels, as shown in the Wild Shape column of the Druid table.

entries.name: Rules While Transformed
entries: While in a form, you retain your personality, memories, and ability to speak, and the following rules apply:

items.name: Game Statistics
entries: Your game statistics are replaced by the statistics of the Beast, but you retain your Hit Points; Hit Dice; Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores; class features; species traits; languages; and feats. You also retain your skill and saving throw proficiencies and use your Proficiency Bonus for them, in addition to gaining those of the creature. If the creature has the same proficiency as you and the bonus in its stat block is higher than yours, use the creature's bonus instead of yours. If the creature has any legendary or lair actions, you can't use them.

items.name: No Spellcasting
entries: You can't cast spells, but transforming doesn't break your Concentration on a spell you've already cast or prevent you from taking actions that are part of a spell, such as Call Lightning, that you've already cast.

items.name: Objects
entries: Your ability to handle objects is determined by the form's limbs, rather than your own. In addition, you choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal, but the DM decides whether it is practical for the new form to wear a piece of equipment, based on the creature's size and shape. Your equipment doesn't change size or shape to match the new form, and any equipment that the new form can't wear must either fall to the ground or merge with it. Equipment that merges with the form has no effect until you leave the form.

classFeature.name: Druid Subclass
entries: You gain a Druid subclass of your choice: Circle of the Land, Circle of the Moon, Circle of the Sea, or Circle of the Stars. Subclasses are detailed after this class's description (for this playtest, use {@class Druid|phb|Circle of Stars|Stars|TCE} from Tasha's Cauldron of Everything).

A subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Druid levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Druid level and lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Wild Resurgence
entries: If you have no uses of Wild Shape left, you can give yourself one use by expending a spell slot (no action required). You can do so only once per turn.

In addition, you can expend one use of Wild Shape (no action required) to give yourself a 1st-level spell slot, and you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Druid Subclass.

classFeature.name: Elemental Fury
entries: The might of the elements flows through you. You gain one of the following options of your choice:

items.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: You add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any Primal cantrip.

items.name: Primal Strike
entries: Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with an attack roll using a weapon or a Beast form's attack in Wild Shape, you can cause the target to take an extra {@damage 1d8} Cold, Fire, Lightning, or Thunder damage (choose when you hit).

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Commune with Nature
entries: You are an expression of nature itself and can commune with the natural world all around you; you always have the Commune with {@skill Nature} spell prepared.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Druid Subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Druid Subclass.

classFeature.name: Improved Elemental Fury
entries: The option you chose for Elemental Fury grows more powerful:

items.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: When you cast a Primal cantrip with a range of 10 feet or greater, the spell's range increases by 300 feet.

items.name: Primal Strike
entries: The extra damage of your Primal Strike increases to {@dice 2d8}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Beast Spells
entries: While using Wild Shape, you can cast spells in Beast form, except for any spell that has a Material component with a cost specified or that consumes its Material component.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Archdruid
entries: The vitality of nature constantly blooms within you, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Evergreen Wild Shape
entries: Whenever you roll Initiative and have no uses of Wild Shape left, you regain one expended use of it.

items.name: Nature Magician
entries: You can convert uses of Wild Shape into a spell slot (no action required). Choose a number of your unexpended uses of Wild Shape and convert them into a single spell slot, with each use contributing 2 spell levels. You must then finish a{@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}before you can do so again. For example, if you convert two uses of Wild Shape, you produce a 4th-level spell slot.

items.name: Longevity
entries: The primal magic that you wield causes you to age more slowly. For every 10 years that pass, your body ages only 1 year.

classFeature.name: Martial Arts
entries: Your practice of martial arts gives you mastery of combat styles that use your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} and Simple Weapons.
You gain the following benefits while you are unarmed or wielding only Simple Weapons and you aren't wearing armor or wielding a shield:

items.name: Bonus Unarmed Strike
entries: When you use the {@action Attack} action with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} or a Simple Weapon on your turn, you can make one {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} as a Bonus Action on the same turn.

items.name: Dexterous Attacks
entries: You can use Dexterity instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls of your Unarmed Strikes and Simple Weapons, except those that have the TwoHanded property.

items.name: Martial Arts Die
entries: You can roll a {@dice d6} in place of the normal damage of your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}. This die changes as you gain Monk levels, as shown in the Martial Arts column of the Monk table.

classFeature.name: Unarmored Defense
entries: While you aren't wearing any armor or wielding a Shield, your base Armor Class equals 10 plus your Dexterity and Wisdom modifiers.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Your training with weapons allows you to use the Mastery property of two kinds of Simple weapons of your choice, such as Daggers and Spears.

Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, you can change the kinds of Simple weapons you chose. For example, you could switch to using the Mastery properties of Maces and Slings.

classFeature.name: Martial Discipline
entries: Your self-discipline and martial training allow you to harness a well of extraordinary energy within yourself. Your access to this energy is represented by a number of Discipline Points. Your Monk level determines the number of points you have, as shown in the Discipline Points column of the Monk table.

You can spend these points to fuel various Martial Discipline features. You start knowing three such features: Flurry of Blows, Patient Defense, and Step of the Wind. You learn more Martial Discipline features as you gain levels in this class.

When you spend a Discipline Point, it is unavailable until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, at the end of which you regain all your expended points.

Some of your Martial Discipline features require your target to make a saving throw to resist the feature's effects. The saving throw DC equals 8 plus your Proficiency Bonus plus your Wisdom modifier.

entries.name: Flurry of Blows
entries: Immediately after you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn, you can spend 1 Discipline Point to make two Unarmed Strikes as a Bonus Action.

entries.name: Patient Defense
entries: You can spend 1 Discipline Point to take the {@action Dodge} action as a Bonus Action.

entries.name: Step of the Wind
entries: You can spend 1 Discipline Point to take both the {@action Disengage} and Dash actions as a Bonus Action, and your jump distance is doubled for the turn.

classFeature.name: Unarmored Movement
entries: Your speed increases by 10 feet while you aren't wearing armor or wielding a Shield. This bonus increases when you reach certain Monk levels, as shown in the Monk table.

classFeature.name: Deflect Missiles
entries: You can use your Reaction to deflect ranged attacks against you that deal Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing damage. When you do so, the damage you take from the attack is reduced by {@dice 1d10} plus your Dexterity modifier plus your Monk level.

If you reduce the damage to 0, you can spend 1 Discipline Point to redirect the attack toward another creature. If you do so, choose a creature within 60 feet of yourself that isn't behind Total Cover. That creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take damage equal to two rolls of your Martial Arts die. The damage is the same type dealt by the attack.

classFeature.name: Monk Subclass
entries: You gain a Monk subclass of your choice: Warrior of Mercy, Warrior of Shadow, Warrior of the Four Elements, or Warrior of the Open Hand. Subclasses are detailed after this class's description (for this playtest, use Way of Mercy from Tasha's Cauldron of Everything for Warrior of Mercy).
A subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Monk levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Monk level and lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Slow Fall
entries: You can use your Reaction when you fall to reduce any damage you take from the fall by an amount equal to five times your Monk level.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Stunning Strike
entries: Once per turn when you hit a creature with a Simple Weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, you can spend 1 Discipline Point to attempt a stunning strike. The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or have the {@condition Stunned} condition until the start of your next turn.

classFeature.name: Empowered Strikes
entries: Whenever you deal damage with your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, it can deal your choice of Force damage or its normal damage type.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Monk subclass.

classFeature.name: Evasion
entries: When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.
You don't benefit from this feature if you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition.

classFeature.name: Heightened Metabolism
entries: If you spend at least 1 minute resting, you can give yourself all the benefits of a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Acrobatic Movement
entries: While you aren't wearing armor or wielding a Shield, you gain the ability to move along vertical surfaces and across liquids on your turn without falling during the movement.

classFeature.name: Self-Restoration
entries: Through sheer force of will, you can use a Bonus Action to remove one of the following conditions from yourself: {@condition Charmed}, {@condition Frightened}, or Poisoned.
In addition, forgoing food and drink doesn't give you levels of Exhaustion.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Monk subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Deflect Energy
entries: You can now use your Deflect Missiles feature against ranged attacks that deal any damage type, not just Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing.

classFeature.name: Disciplined Survivor
entries: Your physical and mental discipline grant you proficiency in all saving throws. Additionally, whenever you make a saving throw and fail, you can spend 1 Discipline Point to reroll it and take the second result.

classFeature.name: Perfect Discipline
entries: When you roll Initiative, you regain 4 expended Discipline Points if you have none remaining.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Monk subclass.

classFeature.name: Superior Defense
entries: As a Bonus Action, you can spend 3 Discipline Points to perfectly bolster yourself against harm for 1 minute or until you are {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.
During that time, you have resistance to all damage except Force damage.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Defy Death
entries: If you drop to 0 Hit Points, you can spend 4 Discipline Points, roll four Martial Arts dice, and add the dice together. Your number of Hit Points instead changes to the total rolled.

Each time you use this feature after the first, the Discipline Point cost increases by 2. When you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, the Discipline Point cost resets to 4.

classFeature.name: Lay on Hands
entries: Your blessed touch can heal wounds. You have a pool of healing power that replenishes when you take a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}. With that pool, you can restore a total number of Hit Points equal to five times your Paladin level.

As a Bonus Action, you can touch a creature (which could be yourself) and draw power from the pool of healing to restore a number of Hit Points to that creature, up to the maximum amount remaining in the pool.
In addition, you can expend 5 Hit Points from the pool of healing to remove the Poisoned condition from the creature, rather than using those points to restore Hit Points.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast spells through prayer, meditation, and devotion. See the Player's Handbook for the rules on spellcasting. The information below details how you use those rules as a Paladin.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Paladin table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

entries.name: Spell Prepared Spells of 1st+ Level
entries: You prepare the list of spells of 1st level and higher that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose two 1st-level spells from the Divine spell list. Rather than choosing, you may start with Heroism and Searing Smite.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Paladin levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Paladin table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional spells from the Divine spell list until the number of spells on your list matches the number on the table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a 5th-level Paladin, your list of prepared spells can include six Divine spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination.

If another Paladin feature gives spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells on the list you prepare with this Spellcasting feature, but those spells otherwise follow the rules in this feature.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, you can replace one spell on your list with another Divine spell for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your Spellcasting Ability for your Paladin spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a Holy Symbol as a Spellcasting Focus for the spells you prepare for this class.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Your training with weapons allows you to use the Mastery property of two kinds of weapons of your choice with which you have proficiency, such as Longswords and Javelins.

Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, you can change the kinds of weapons you chose. For example, you could switch to using the Mastery properties of Halberds and Flails.

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: You have honed your martial prowess. You gain one of the following Fighting Style feats of your choice: Defense, Dueling, Great Weapon Fighting, or Protection.

classFeature.name: Paladin's Smite
entries: You have mastered smiting your targets with divine energy. You always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Paladin level specified in the Smite Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

In addition, you can cast one of your prepared spells from this feature without expending a spell slot, and you must finish a{@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}before you use this benefit again.

classFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: You can channel divine energy directly from the Outer Planes, using that energy to fuel magical effects. You start with one such effect: Divine Sense, which is described below. Other Paladin features give additional Channel Divinity effect options. Each time you use this Channel Divinity, you choose which effect to create from among those you have from this class.

You can use Channel Divinity twice. You regain one expended use when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}. You gain additional uses when you reach certain Paladin levels, as shown in the Channel Divinity column of the Paladin table.
If a Channel Divinity effect requires a saving throw, the DC equals the Spell Save DC from this class's Spellcasting feature.

entries.name: Divine Sense
entries: As a Bonus Action, you can open your awareness to detect Celestials, Fiends, and Undead. For the next 10 minutes or until you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition, you know the location of any creature of those types within 60 feet of yourself, and you know its creature type. Within the same radius, you also detect the presence of any place or object that has been consecrated or desecrated, as with the {@spell Hallow} spell.

classFeature.name: Paladin Subclass
entries: You gain a Paladin subclass of your choice: Oath of Devotion, Oath of Glory, Oath of the Ancients, or Oath of Vengeance. Subclasses are detailed after this class's description.

A subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Paladin levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Paladin level and lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Faithful Steed
entries: You can easily call on the aid of an otherworldly steed. You always have the {@spell Find Steed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} spell prepared.
You can also cast the spell once without expending a spell slot, and you regain the ability to do so when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

classFeature.name: Aura of Protection
entries: You radiate a protective, {@condition invisible} aura that extends 10 feet from you in every direction, but it doesn't extend through Total Cover. The aura is inactive while you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition.
You and your allies in the aura gain a bonus to saving throws equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum bonus of +1).
If another Paladin is present, a creature can benefit from only one Aura of Protection at a time; the creature chooses which one when entering the auras.

classFeature.name: Aura of Protection
entries: You radiate a protective, {@condition Invisible|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} aura that extends 10 feet from you in every direction, but it doesn't extend through Total Cover.
You and your allies in the aura gain a bonus to saving throws equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum bonus of +1).
If another Paladin is present, a creature can benefit from only one Aura of Protection at a time; the creature chooses which one when entering the auras.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Paladin Subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Abjure Foes
entries: As a {@action Magic|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} action, you can expend one use of your Channel Divinity to overwhelm foes with divine awe. As you present your Holy Symbol or weapon, you can target a number of creatures equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one creature) that you can see within 60 feet of yourself.

Each target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Dazed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} and {@condition Frightened} conditions for 1 minute or until it takes any damage. On a successful save, the target has the {@condition Dazed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition for 1 minute or until it takes any damage.

classFeature.name: Aura of Courage
entries: You and your allies are immune to the {@condition Frightened} condition while in your Aura of Protection. If a {@condition Frightened} ally enters the aura, that condition has no effect on that ally while there.

classFeature.name: Radiant Strikes
entries: You are so suffused with divine might that your weapon strikes carry supernatural power with them. When you hit a target with an attack roll using a melee weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d8} Radiant damage.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Restoring Touch
entries: When you use Lay on Hands on a creature, you can also remove one or more of the following conditions from the creature: {@condition Blinded}, {@condition Charmed}, {@condition Dazed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, {@condition Deafened}, {@condition Frightened}, {@condition Paralyzed}, or {@condition Stunned}. You must expend 5 Hit Points from the healing pool of Lay on Hands for each of these conditions you remove; those points don't also restore Hit Points to the creature.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Paladin Subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Aura Expansion
entries: Your Aura of Protection now extends 30 feet from you rather than 10 feet.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Paladin Subclass.

classFeature.name: Deft Explorer
entries: You are an unsurpassed explorer. Choose one of your proficiencies in a skill that appears on the Ranger skill list. You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} in that skill.

In addition, choose two types of terrain: arctic, coast, desert, forest, grassland, mountain, swamp, or the Underdark. You have Advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) checks about the chosen terrains, and you have Advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks to track creatures in them.
Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, you can meditate and replace one of the chosen terrain types with a different one from the list.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to channel the magical essence of nature to cast spells. See the Player's Handbook for the rules on spellcasting. The information below details how you use those rules as a Ranger.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Ranger table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of 1st+ Level
entries: You prepare the list of spells of 1st level and higher that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose two 1st-level spells from the Primal spell list. Rather than choosing, you may start with Cure Wounds and Ensnaring Strike.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Ranger levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Ranger table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional spells from the Primal spell list until the number of spells on your list matches the number on the table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a 5th-level Ranger, your list of prepared spells can include six Primal spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination.

If another Ranger feature gives spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells on the list you prepare with this Spellcasting feature, but those spells otherwise follow the rules in this feature.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, you can replace one spell on your list with another Primal spell for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your Spellcasting Ability for your Ranger Spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a Druidic Focus as a Spellcasting Focus for the Spells you prepare for this Class.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Your training with weapons allows you to use the Mastery property of two kinds of weapons of your choice with which you have proficiency, such as Longbows and Longswords.

Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, you can change the kinds of weapons you chose. For example, you could switch to using the Mastery properties of Scimitars and Shortswords.

classFeature.name: Favored Enemy
entries: You are adept at focusing on a single foe. You always have the Hunter's Mark spell prepared. You can cast it a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once) without expending a spell slot, and you regain all expended uses of this ability when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: You have honed your martial prowess. You gain one of the following Fighting Style feats of your choice: Archery, Defense, Dueling, or TwoWeapon Fighting.

classFeature.name: Ranger Subclass
entries: You gain a Ranger subclass of your choice: Beast Master, Fey Wanderer, Gloom Stalker, or Hunter. Subclasses are detailed after this class's description (for this playtest, use {@class Ranger|phb|Fey Wanderer|Fey Wanderer|TCE} from Tasha's Cauldron of Everything). A subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Ranger levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Ranger level and lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} on your turn.

classFeature.name: Roving
entries: Your Speed increases by 10 feet while you aren't wearing Heavy Armor.
You also have a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} and a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} equal to your Speed.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Ranger Subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Conjure Barrage
entries: Channeling nature's might, you can cause your weapon to multiply and strike at creatures before you; you always have the {@spell Conjure Barrage|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} spell prepared.

classFeature.name: Deft Explorer Improvement
entries: Choose one of your proficiencies in a skill that appears on the Ranger skill list. You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} in that skill.
In addition, choose two more terrain types for your Deft Explorer feature.

classFeature.name: Tireless
entries: Primal forces now help fuel you on your journeys, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Temporary Hit Points
entries: As an action, you can give yourself a number of Temporary Hit Points equal to {@dice 1d8} plus your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1). You can use this action a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

items.name: Decrease Exhaustion
entries: Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, your Exhaustion level, if any, decreases by 1.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Ranger Subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Nature's Veil
entries: You invoke spirits of nature to magically hide yourself from view. As a Bonus Action, you can give yourself the {@condition Invisible|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition until the end of your next turn.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Ranger Subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Conjure Volley
entries: Propelled by primal spirits, your weapon can strike a group of targets far away; you always have the {@spell Conjure Volley|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} spell prepared.

classFeature.name: Feral Senses
entries: Your connection to the forces of nature grants you {@feat Blindsight|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} with a range of 30 feet.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Foe Slayer
entries: You become an unparalleled hunter of your foes. When your attack roll misses the target of your Hunter's Mark, you can add your Wisdom modifier to the attack roll, potentially turning it into a hit.
In addition, whenever you hit that target with an attack roll and deal damage to it, you c

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} in two of your Skill Proficiencies of your choice.
{@skill Sleight of Hand} and {@skill Stealth} are iconic choices for a Rogue if you have Proficiency in them.

classFeature.name: Sneak Attack
entries: You know how to turn a subtle attack into a deadly one. Once on each of your turns when you take the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} Action, you can deal extra damage to one creature you hit with an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} if you're attacking with a Finesse Weapon or a Ranged Weapon and if at least one of the following requirements is met:

items.name: Advantage
entries: You have Advantage on the {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

items.name: Ally Adjacent to Target
entries: At least one of your allies is within 5 feet of the target, the ally isn't {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, and you don't have Disadvantage on the {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6|Attack Roll.}

To determine the extra damage, roll a number of d6s equal to half your Rogue level (round up), and add the dice together (the Rogue table shows the number of Sneak Attack dice you get at each Rogue level). The extra damage's type is the same as the weapon's Damage Type.

classFeature.name: Thieves' Cant
entries: You picked up various languages in the communities where you plied your roguish talents. You know Thieves' Cant and one other language of your choice, which you choose from the Standard Languages and Rare Languages tables.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Your training with weapons allows you to use the Mastery property of two kinds of weapons of your choice with which you have proficiency, such as Daggers and Shortbows.

Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, you can change the kinds of weapons you chose. For example, you could switch to using the Mastery properties of Scimitars and Shortswords.

classFeature.name: Cunning Action
entries: Your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. On your turn, you can take one of the following Actions as a Bonus Action: {@action Dash|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Hide|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

classFeature.name: Rogue Subclass
entries: You gain a Rogue subclass of your choice: Arcane Trickster, Assassin, Swashbuckler, or Thief. Subclasses are detailed after this class's description.

A subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Rogue levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Rogue level and lower.

classFeature.name: Steady Aim
entries: As a Bonus Action, you give yourself Advantage on your next attack roll on the current turn. You can use this feature only if you haven't moved during this turn, and after you use it, your Speed is 0 until the end of the current turn.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Cunning Strike
entries: You have developed cunning ways to use your Sneak Attack. When you deal Sneak Attack damage, you can add one of the following Cunning Strike effects. Each effect has a die cost, which is the number of Sneak Attack damage dice you must forego to add the effect. You remove the die before rolling, and the effect occurs immediately after the attack's damage is dealt. For example, if you add the Poison effect, remove {@dice 1d6} from the Sneak Attack's damage before rolling.
If a Cunning Strike effect requires a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your Proficiency Bonus + your Dexterity modifier.

items.name: Disarm (Cost: 1d6)
entries: The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw, or it drops one item of your choice that it's holding.

items.name: Poison (Cost: 1d6)
entries: You add a toxin to your strike, forcing the target to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target has the Poisoned condition for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns, the Poisoned target can repeat the save, ending the effect on itself on a success. To use this effect, you must have a Poisoner's Kit on your person.

items.name: Trip (Cost: 1d6)
entries: If the target is Large or smaller, it must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or have the {@condition Prone} condition.

items.name: Withdraw (Cost: 1d6)
entries: Immediately after the attack, you move up to half your Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks.

classFeature.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: When an attacker that you can see hits you with an {@action Attack|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6|Attack Roll}, you can use your Reaction to halve the attack's damage against you (round down).

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} in two of your Skill Proficiencies of your choice.

classFeature.name: Evasion
entries: You can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain dangers. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw and only half damage if you fail. You can't use this feature if you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition.

classFeature.name: Reliable Talent
entries: You have refined your talents until they approach perfection. Whenever you make an ability check that uses one of your skill or Tool proficiencies, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Rogue Subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Improved Cunning Strike
entries: You can use up to two Cunning Strike effects when you deal Sneak Attack damage, paying the die cost for each effect.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Rogue Subclass.

classFeature.name: Devious Strikes
entries: You have practiced new ways to use your Sneak Attack deviously. The following effects are now among your Cunning Strike options.

items.name: Daze (Cost: 2d6)
entries: The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw, or it has the {@condition Dazed|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition until the end of its next turn.

items.name: Knock Out (Cost: 6d6)
entries: The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw, or it has the Unconscious condition for 1 minute or until it takes any damage. The Unconscious target can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: Obscure (Cost: 3d6)
entries: You strike near the target's eyes. The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw, or it has the Blinded condition until the end of its next turn.

classFeature.name: Slippery Mind
entries: Your cunning mind is exceptionally difficult to control. You gain Proficiency in Wisdom and Charisma Saving Throws.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Rogue Subclass.

classFeature.name: Elusive
entries: You are so evasive that attackers rarely gain the upper hand against you. No attack roll can have Advantage against you unless you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Stroke of Luck
entries: You have an uncanny knack for succeeding when you need to. If you fail a {@variantrule D20 Tests|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6|d20 Test}, you can turn the roll into a 20.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

subclassFeature.name: College of Dance
entries: Bards of the College of Dance know that the Words of Creation can't be contained within speech or even song; they are uttered by the movements of celestial bodies and flow through the motions of even the smallest creatures. To these Bards, dance is art freed from the constraints of a single point in space and time; it is meaning unconfined by narrow definitions of words and structures of grammar. The College of Dance practices a way of being in harmony with the ever-whirling cosmos, emphasizing agility, speed, and grace.

subclassFeature.name: Dazzling Footwork
entries: Your practice of dance gives you the ability to gracefully dodge and make agile strikes. While you aren't wearing armor or wielding a Shield, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Unarmored Defense
entries: Your base Armor Class equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Charisma modifier.

items.name: Agile Strikes
entries: When you expend a use of your Bardic Inspiration as part of an action, a Bonus Action, or a Reaction, you can make one {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} as part of that action, Bonus Action, or Reaction.

items.name: Bardic Damage
entries: You can use Dexterity instead of Strength for the attack rolls of your Unarmed Strikes, and when you deal damage with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}, you can deal Bludgeoning damage equal to a roll of your Bardic Inspiration die plus your Dexterity modifier. This roll doesn't expend the die.

subclassFeature.name: Inspiring Movement
entries: When an enemy you can see ends its turn within 5 feet of an ally of yours who is within 60 feet of you, you can use your Reaction and expend one use of your Bardic Inspiration to move up to half your Speed. Then roll your Bardic Inspiration die, and the ally can move up to a number of feet equal to 5 times the number rolled. None of this feature's movement provokes Opportunity Attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Leading Evasion
entries: When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and you take only half damage if you fail. If any creatures within 5 feet of you are making the same Dexterity saving throw, you can share this benefit with them for that save.
You can't use this feature if you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition.

subclassFeature.name: Tandem Footwork
entries: When you roll Initiative, you can spend one use of your Bardic Inspiration if you don't have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition. When you do so, roll your Bardic Inspiration die, and choose a number of creatures within 60 feet of yourself (you can choose yourself), up to a number equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one creature). Each of them gains a bonus to their Initiative equal to the number rolled.

subclassFeature.name: Irresistible Dance
entries: You always have the Otto's Irresistible Dance spell prepared. You can cast it without expending a spell slot. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}. You can also restore your use of the feature by expending four uses of your Bardic Inspiration (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: College of Glamour
entries: The College of Glamour traces its origins to the beguiling magic of the Feywild. The Bards who study this magic weave threads of beauty and terror into their songs and stories, and the mightiest among them can cloak themselves in otherworldly majesty. Their performances stir up wistful longing for forgotten innocence, evoke {@condition unconscious} memories of long-held fears, and tug at the emotions of even the most hardhearted listeners.

subclassFeature.name: Beguiling Magic
entries: You always have the {@spell Charm Person} and {@spell Mirror Image} spells prepared.

In addition, immediately after you cast an Enchantment or Illusion spell, you can cause a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself to make a Wisdom saving throw against your Spell Save DC. On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Charmed} or {@condition Frightened} condition (your choice) for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Once you use this benefit, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}. You can also restore your use of the feature by expending one use of your Bardic Inspiration (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Mantle of Inspiration
entries: You can weave fey magic into a song or dance to fill others with vigor. As a Bonus Action, you can expend a use of Bardic Inspiration, rolling a Bardic Inspiration die. When you do so, choose a number of other creatures within 60 feet of yourself, up to a number equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one creature). Each of them gains a number of Temporary Hit Points equal to 2 times the number rolled on the Bardic Inspiration die, and then each of them can use its Reaction to move up to its Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Mantle of Majesty
entries: You always have the {@spell Command} spell prepared.

As a Bonus Action, you cast {@spell Command} without expending a spell slot, and you take on an unearthly appearance for 1 minute or until your Concentration ends (as if you were {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell). During this time, you can cast {@spell Command} as a Bonus Action without expending a spell slot.
Any creature {@condition Charmed} by you automatically fails its saving throw against the Command you cast with this feature.

Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}. You can also restore your use of the feature by expending a spell slot of 3rd level or higher (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Unbreakable Majesty
entries: As a Bonus Action, you can assume a magically majestic presence for 1 minute or until you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} condition. For the duration, whenever any creature hits you with an attack roll for the first time on a turn, the attacker must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your Spell Save DC, or the attack misses instead, as the creature recoils from your majesty.
Once you assume this majestic presence, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6}.

subclassFeature.name: College of Lore
entries: Bards of the College of Lore plumb the depths of magical knowledge, collecting spells and secrets from sources as diverse as scholarly tomes, mystical rites, and peasant tales. The college's members gather in libraries and universities to share their lore with one another. They also meet at festivals or affairs of state, where they can expose corruption, unravel lies, and poke fun at self-important figures of authority.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: You gain proficiency with three skills of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Cutting Words
entries: You learn how to use your wit to supernaturally distract, confuse, and otherwise sap the confidence and competence of others. When a creature that you can see within 60 feet of you makes a damage roll or succeeds on an ability check or attack roll, you can use your Reaction to expend one use of your Bardic Inspiration, roll your Bardic Inspiration die, and subtract the number rolled from the creature's roll, reducing the damage or potentially turning the success into a failure.

subclassFeature.name: Magical Discoveries
entries: You learn two spells of your choice. These spells can come from the Arcane, Divine, or Primal spell list or any combination thereof. A spell you choose must be a cantrip or a spell for which you have spell slots, as shown on the Bard table.
You always have the chosen spells prepared, and whenever you gain a Bard level, you can replace one of the spells with another spell that meets the requirements above.

subclassFeature.name: Peerless Skill
entries: When you make an ability check or attack roll and fail, you can expend one use of Bardic Inspiration, roll the Bardic Inspiration die, and add the number rolled to the {@dice d20}, potentially turning a failure into a success. On a failure, the Bardic Inspiration isn't expended.

subclassFeature.name: College of Valor
entries: Bards of the College of Valor are daring storytellers whose tales keep alive the memory of the great heroes of the past. These Bards sing the deeds of the mighty, both past and present, in vaulted halls or to crowds gathered around great bonfires. They travel the land to witness great events firsthand and to ensure that the memory of these events doesn't pass from the world. With their songs, they inspire new generations to reach the same heights of accomplishment as the heroes of old.

subclassFeature.name: Combat Inspiration
entries: You can use your wit to turn the tide of battle. A creature that has a Bardic Inspiration die from you can use it for one of the following effects:

items.name: Defense
entries: When the creature is hit by an attack roll, that creature can use its Reaction to roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to its AC against that attack, potentially causing the attack to miss.

items.name: Offense
entries: Immediately after the creature hits a target with an attack roll, the creature can roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to the attack's damage against the target.

subclassFeature.name: Martial Training
entries: You gain proficiency with Martial Weapons and {@variantrule Armor Training|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6} with Medium Armor and Shields.
In addition, you can use a Simple or Martial weapon as a spellcasting focus to cast spells from your Bard spell list.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Battle Magic
entries: After you cast a spell that has a casting time of an action, you can make one attack with a weapon as a Bonus Action.

subclassFeature.name: Life Domain
entries: The Life Domain focuses on the vibrant positive energy—one of the fundamental forces of the universe—that sustains all life. The Clerics who tap into this domain are masters of healing, using that force of life to cure many hurts.

Existence itself relies on the positive energy associated with this domain, so a Cleric of any religious tradition might choose it. This domain is associated with agricultural deities, sun gods, gods of healing or endurance, and gods of home and community. Religious orders of healing also seek the powers of this domain.

subclassFeature.name: Disciple of Life
entries: Your healing spells are empowered by life itself. When a spell you cast with a spell slot restores Hit Points to a creature, that creature regains additional Hit Points on the turn you cast the spell. The additional Hit Points equal 2 plus the spell slot's level.

subclassFeature.name: Domain Spells
entries: Your connection to this divine domain ensures you always have certain spells ready. When you reach a Cleric level specified in the Life Domain Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Life Domain Spells
rows: {@spell Aid}, {@spell Bless}, {@spell Cure Wounds}, {@spell Lesser Restoration}

subclassFeature.name: Preserve Life
entries: As part of casting a prepared Abjuration spell from the Divine spell list, you can expend uses of Channel Divinity to create a spell slot to use for the casting. You must expend a number of Channel Divinity uses equal to the spell's level. For example, you can expend one use of Channel Divinity to create a 1st-level spell slot for a casting of Shield of Faith if you have that spell prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Blessed Healer
entries: The healing spells you cast on others heal you as well. Immediately after you cast a spell with a spell slot that restores Hit Points to one creature other than you, you regain Hit Points equal to 2 plus the spell slot's level.

subclassFeature.name: Supreme Healing
entries: When you would normally roll one or more dice to restore Hit Points to a creature with a spell or Channel Divinity, don't roll those dice for the healing; instead use the highest number possible for each die. For example, instead of restoring {@dice 2d6} Hit Points to a creature with a spell, you restore 12.

subclassFeature.name: Light Domain
entries: The Light Domain emphasizes the divine power to bring about blazing fire and revelation. Clerics who wield this power are enlightened souls infused with radiance and the power of their deities' discerning vision, charged with chasing away lies and burning away darkness.

The Light Domain is associated with gods of truth, vigilance, beauty, insight, and renewal. Some of these gods are identified with the sun or as charioteers who guide the sun across the sky. Others are sentinels who pierce every shadow and deception. Some are deities of beauty and artistry, who teach that art is a vehicle for the soul's improvement. Religious orders focused on combating the Undead also draw on the power of this domain.

subclassFeature.name: Domain Spells
entries: Your connection to this divine domain ensures you always have certain spells ready. When you reach a Cleric level specified in the Light Domain Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Light Domain Spells
rows: {@spell Burning Hands}, {@spell Faerie Fire}, {@spell Moonbeam}, {@spell See Invisibility}

subclassFeature.name: Radiance of the Dawn
entries: As a {@action Magic|XUA2023PlayersHandbookP6|Magic Action}, you present your Holy Symbol and expend a use of your Channel Divinity to emit sunlight in a 30-foot-radius sphere centered on yourself. Any magical darkness—such as that created by the {@spell Darkness} spell—in the sphere is dispelled. Additionally, each creature of your choice in the sphere must make a Constitution saving throw, taking Radiant damage equal to {@dice 2d10} + your Cleric level on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
